instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.LP8550: What is LP8550? This is an LED driver responsible for creating the backlight on the LCD screen of Macbooks from 2011 through 2015.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.BKL_PWM: What is BKL_PWM? BKL_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..
definitions.BKL_EN: What is BKL_EN? BKL_EN enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .
definitions.BKLT_EN: What is BKLT_EN? This signal enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKLT” before “_EN”. “BKLT” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .
definitions.Q7706: What is Q7706? Q7706 takes PPBUS_G3H's main 12.6v and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q7706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R7788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q7706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..
definitions.D7701: What is D7701? diode in the backlight circuit sitting between the BKL_SW pin of the LED driver and backlight output. Very common for via between this and BKL_FB for feedback to blow, causing no boost. Measure continuity between pin 2 of this diode and feedback pin of LED driver if backlight output is PPBUS_G3H with no boost.
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight flickering
threads.message:
Hi.

I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with backlight flickering after liquid damage on and around LP85550. I have replaced <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> and all surrounding components.

<SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> - 2.78 V and up. Not steady.

<SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> - 1.473v steady

<SIGNAL>PPHV_SOSW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> - 24V - 26V Fluctuates.

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> - 5V Steady

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> - 3.3V Steady

Tried 2 <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP>'s

Zero damage to LCD connector or surrounding area.

Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight flickering
threads.message:
Did you check XW7720?
Also check all LED return resistors.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight flickering
threads.message: Tried known good screen as well as DC-in board/flex? <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> should be steady not up and down. Replaced both resistors? LED driver soldered properly?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight flickering
threads.message:
If you make a short D-S on <TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR> (pins 1-6), do you get stable backlight?
If yes, check for corrosion arround <TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR>/07 and <RESISTOR>R7788</RESISTOR>/89; possibly need to remove <CAPACITOR>C7782</CAPACITOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight flickering
threads.message:
Hello.

So far I tried 3 known good screens. 2 known good DC-IN boards and cables. All 6 LCD Return resistors are around 0 Ohm. Tried 3 <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP>'s.

Put steady 3V on <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> just in case. XW7720 is clean and not damaged at all. Continuity between pin 2 XW2770 and pin 2 <DIODE>D7701</DIODE> strong.

Tried shorting pin 1 - 6  <TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR>. Did blanket replacement on both <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> area and L7701 area,

Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight flickering
threads.message: Jeez what a mess that sounds awful. Maybe corrosion under the SMC messing with <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> signal?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight flickering
threads.message: Post diode mode to ground on ALL connections of <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight flickering
threads.message: Could very well be bad SMC messing with LID line if corroded originally. Try a new one to rule that out.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight flickering
threads.message: Gotcha, will do. Thanks.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight flickering
threads.message: "?????????" , was a mistype. sorry.

threads.message: Backlight still flickers?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight flickering
threads.message:
Hi!

Replaced SMC with same issues present.

Pads (34)<SIGNAL>NC_BDV_BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> and (96) were damaged. But they are (NC) so I am assuming that they are not connected.

Thanks!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight flickering
threads.message:
SMC is not involved in backlight flickering.
Unless <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> is not stable.

Do you note the same flickers with low and high backlight level?
Did you try with known good LCD assembly?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight flickering
threads.message: That just sounds downright awful at this point lol

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight flickering
threads.message:

[url]https://photos.app.goo.gl/PAQYbsVUyYQuk1yd8[/url]


First link with original screen. Second link with entirely different display and body. 

Quality gets way worse with some theatre light effects at lower backlight level and actually completely turned off at one point. I have tried 3 different <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP>'s so far so I dont think its that. Unless the entire strip that i have is bad, lol!

Yea [USER="1153"]JohnB8812[/USER] , this blows lol. I usually am closed on Monday but came in just for this... Awesome :cool:.

Thanks again!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight flickering
threads.message:
Reflow <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> and gently tap it on top, to see it dancing a bit.
This will assure  all solders are good.
I had something like that with bad solders; got more flickers at low backlight level.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight flickering
threads.message:
Hi.

Reflowed <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> and replaced with <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> from donor as well. Replaced LCD connector just in case even though there was zero damage.
No louck. Think Im gonna throw in the towel on this.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight flickering
threads.message:
Do few PRAM reset before.
Also remove <RESISTOR>R7704</RESISTOR> and run a wire from <CAPACITOR>C7704</CAPACITOR> to <RESISTOR>R7715</RESISTOR>.
If still flickers, remove <RESISTOR>R7731</RESISTOR> and run another wire from <RESISTOR>R7715</RESISTOR> to <CAPACITOR>C7711</CAPACITOR>.
In this way you force both backlight controls to maxim.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> backlight flickering
threads.message:
OK.

Did 3 or 4 PRAM's.

Removed <RESISTOR>R7704</RESISTOR>, then connected <CAPACITOR>C7704</CAPACITOR> and <RESISTOR>R7715</RESISTOR>. = Still flickers

Removed <RESISTOR>R7731</RESISTOR>, then connected <RESISTOR>R7715</RESISTOR> and <CAPACITOR>C7711</CAPACITOR>. = No Backlight at all.

Thanks for sticking it out, lol.

[url]https://photos.app.goo.gl/5XeGEEpV4au6NzgHA[/url]
